title: Particle motion from velocity graph part - d

content.description: A car is traveling on a straight road. For <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>24</mn> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3CAB@</annotation> </semantics> </math> seconds, the car's velocity v(t), in meters per second, is modeled by the piecewise-linear function defined by the graph above.
content.question: Find the average rate of change of v over the interval <math> <mrow> <mn>8</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow> </math>. Does the Mean Value Theorem guarantee a value of c, for 8 < c < 20, such that v'(c) is equal to this average rate of change? Why or why not?

frqParts.text: Find the average rate of change of v over the interval <math> <mrow> <mn>8</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow> </math>. Does the Mean Value Theorem guarantee a value of c, for 8 < c < 20, such that v'(c) is equal to this average rate of change? Why or why not?

topic.text: 2.1: Defining Average and Instantaneous Rates of Change at a Point

skill.text: Skill 3.C: Confirm whether hypotheses or conditions of a selected definition, theorem, or test have been satisfied.
